Warhammer 40,000: Gladius – Relics of War proves once and for all that in the grim darkness of the far future there is only war… and apparently that’s still not enough to satisfy a proper 4X strategy fan. But Gladius gives it a solid try.

With only four factions, you might think the galaxy feels a bit empty, but each faction is crafted with such care and personality that you’ll forget you ever wanted more. Every playthrough feels distinct whether you’re fielding Space Marines with the subtlety of a meteor strike or shambling across the map as Necrons who treat diplomacy the same way they treat the living: with deep, unwavering contempt.

Honestly, what were people expecting? Diplomacy? Trade deals? Peace treaties? Did anyone truly imagine sitting across the negotiation table from Necrons? Negotiating? With them? Fools. There is no peace here only beautifully structured, endlessly entertaining, turn-based annihilation.

In short: a great addition to the 4X lineup, provided you like your strategy games like your grimdark futures loud, violent, and absolutely allergic to diplomacy.

If you’re a Warhammer 40K fan or you enjoy 4X strategy games with a strong focus on warfare, Gladius is absolutely worth your time. Unlike many other 4X titles that try to balance diplomacy, culture, and science, Gladius fully commits to what the 40K universe is all about: brutal, relentless conflict—and it does it extremely well.

Each faction feels unique, from their mechanics to their playstyles, and learning how to master them is a big part of the fun. The moment-to-moment gameplay is tense and rewarding, especially when you finally unlock powerful units and watch them turn the tide of battle. The map generation, quests, and neutral creatures also add a good amount of variety to each playthrough.

The game is easy to get into but has enough depth to keep you engaged for dozens of hours. It’s especially fun in multiplayer with friends—matches can get intense quickly, and every decision matters.

If you want a pure, combat-heavy 4X experience set in the grimdark future of Warhammer 40,000, Gladius is one of the best out there. Highly recommended.

Ignore any review that mentions diplomacy. It's of the same worth as a complaint about a lack of diplomacy in Tetris: it belies a fundamental misconception. It's Warhammer, not Friendhammer. "There is only war" is a fundamental aspect of the IP, and Gladius is wholly, beautifully in line with it.

Incredibly in-depth 4X turn-based strategy game, with thoughtfully crafted graphics that transport you into a world of futuristic warfare.

Different factions have their own special abilities and tactical options that you can use to your advantage. Different types of terrain, such as forests and mountains add to the challenge and make it much more tactical and interesting.
The UI is simple and easy to understand, easing new players into the game. You can also customize your units with different weapons and even upgrade them as you progress through the game. I was particularly pleased with the extensive research system which gives you access to powerful tech as you progress.

Overall, a great game that 4X turn-based strategy fans should definitely check out. All in all, I highly recommend Warhammer 40K Gladius for strategy gamers.

(A note about DLC: this game was made by 2 coders and a writer a few years ago. Every six months, there is a DLC, either a unit pack or a new faction. They include DLC units on the tech tree for some reason, and this makes people angry, thinking there's a paywall for units that weren't in the game until 2 years after release. Don't be fooled, it's a good and fair support cycle).

For fans of the Warhammer 40K universe, the game is a treasure trove of lore. It successfully integrates the rich backstory of the factions into the gameplay, making every victory feel meaningful.

Warhammer 40,000: Gladius is a slightly clunky CIV game that focuses solely on city building and growing your war machine.  This works perfectly for a Warhammer 40k setting: In the grim darkness of the far future there is only war, so what else would you expect?  What it lacks in varying victory conditions it makes up for in focused strategic gameplay. The scale of the battles, especially mid-late game are magnificent and very fun.  It is both addicting (just one more turn) and faster paced than other 4x games.  I tend not to finish too many CIV games because I find the late game grind less fun.  But I have the opposite feeling with Gladius, I find the late game more fun and rewarding and action oriented, so I've tended to finish a good number of games I've started.  There is a lot of lore to read (which I like) and a ton of units and deep tech trees.  Each faction feels very unique and many play very differently from each other.  It takes more than one game for me to "get" a faction.  Another positive is there is solid mod support in the workshop, which brings more flavor to the game.  It's a very fun game, and the more I play the more I like it.

Some negatives, as I said at the start, the GUI and presentation are a little clunky. Many things aren't explained well and the in game dictionary is a pain to use with no search function.  But luckily there are websites to help. The main negative is one others have mentioned.  If you want to buy this game with all of the DLC's (there's so many) it will cost you about the same as buying a real plastic army from Games Workshop..  Meaning it's expensive, way too expensive for a PC game.  But it does go on sale a lot, and you can pick and choose the DLC you are interested in. Still that business model isn't my cup of tea.

TL;DR edition, it's a good game but hampered by it's DLC policy and pricing, and it makes me angry.

I've seen people recommend this game while mentioning the same arguments as I have, and frankly I've enjoyed my time with the game. That’s why I'm on the fence not recommending it. If you're prepared to pay for it, or of there's a good discount, you can get it and have fun with it, the game itself is good.

I've completed 1.5 playthroughs as of now, without any DLCs. I'm not very proficient in 4x games, but I do love them, ever since Civ 1. Gameplay-wise it's basically Civ 5-6 but with WH40K, no diplomacy and more fighting instead. Reminds me of Civ 5 scenario "Empires of the Smoky Skies" since the game is set in one technological era. And I like that kind of gameplay. I like that the planet feels grim-dark, the landscape is oppressive, hard to traverse and has hazards that damage your troops, and has much more of wild life barbarian enemies who feel threatening.

That said, the base game is incredibly barren, 4 factions with half a roster each. I can't really complain since I've got the game for free couple of years back... No wait, this is internet, I can complain however I want! 
So yeah, even though there are eleven factions, you can only play as four. not only that, your enemies are also limited to the same 4. So its just orks/necron/guards/marines all game every game. and those DLC for factions are there taunting you to buy them. one. faction. at. a. time. and say for example you don't want to play most factions, but if you still want to play against them - you have to buy their DLC. I have to repeat this, You have to by DLC factions you don't want to play. 

And that's not all, we still have the 9 DLC with units for factions, each having 4-8 units for several factions, spread out like a thin layer of butter over everything, each DLC adding another one. and those aren't some extra, there are core units in there. Want an APC for your guards? Chimera is a DLC unit? Land raider? in another DLC with stuff you might not care about for other races. Immortals? DLC again. so that's like almost half the roster locked behind a wall of DLCs, starting 4 factions are especially gimped. Space marines have it the worst, one DLC has 8 of their units. Yeah you also have to buy them for AI to play too even if you're not interested. That's 16 DLC total, and approaches Paradox levels of nickel-and-diming.

Those are not cheap DLCs either, going for like 16.5 euro for a faction and 6-10 euro for a reinforcement pack. That's almost 200 euro worth of DLCs on top of 40 euro for a base game (released in 2018, 7 years ago). DLCs you won't easily be able to ignore, as I've said. Sales? 40% tops. Season passes or bundles? You get complete edition bundle with like 20% discount for 190 euros for the game + all DLCs and that’s it. Truly a Games Workshop product

Not even that, take something like Total War Warhammer for example. True, there's even more DLCs, over three games, but they are better priced, better discounted, better grouped, and most importantly, available for AI to use. You don't have to pay for a shiny new chaos dwarf DLC if you just want to krump them in your game, they get added in a patch with other quality of life upgrades. You can stick to your starting roster if you like and have lot's of variety in your enemies. If you feel so inclined, you can pick up another faction DLC and have a comprehensive playthrough without being hamstrung by the fact you don't own every other DLC first. And DLCs are crossgame, you buy Norsca in TW:W1, you can play them in TW:W13 if you want. Even stupid blood god dlc you only have to buy once and it's very cheap.

See, that's what I expected going into Gladius. TW:W1 also predates Gladius by 2 years, so the precedent was there. Another good option would be to have cheaper bundles or maybe season passes. Currently I just think that Gladius has a petty policy and is way too expensive for what it is. From what I gather, the developer's next game, ZEPHON, is much better in this regard. True, it lacks wh40k IP, but I think I'd rather play ZEPHON than Gladius.

Oh, and soundtrack is kinda meh.

I've completed 1.5 playthroughs as of now, without any DLCs. I'm not very proficient in 4x games, but I do love them, ever since Civ 1. Gameplay-wise it's basically Civ 5-6 but with WH40K, no diplomacy and more fighting instead. Reminds me of Civ 5 scenario "Empires of the Smoky Skies" since the game is set in one technological era. And I like that kind of gameplay. I like that the planet feels grim-dark, the landscape is oppressive, hard to traverse and has hazards that damage your troops, and has much more of wild life barbarian enemies who feel threatening.

That said, the base game is incredibly barren, 4 factions with half a roster each. I can't really complain since I've got the game for free couple of years back... No wait, this is internet, I can complain however I want! 
So yeah, even though there are eleven factions, you can only play as four. not only that, your enemies are also limited to the same 4. So its just orks/necron/guards/marines all game every game. and those DLC for factions are there taunting you to buy them. one. faction. at. a. time. and say for example you don't want to play most factions, but if you still want to play against them - you have to buy their DLC. I have to repeat this, You have to by DLC factions you don't want to play. 

And that's not all, we still have the 9 DLC with units for factions, each having 4-8 units for several factions, spread out like a thin layer of butter over everything, each DLC adding another one. and those aren't some extra, there are core units in there. Want an APC for your guards? Chimera is a DLC unit? Land raider? in another DLC with stuff you might not care about for other races. Immortals? DLC again. so that's like almost half the roster locked behind a wall of DLCs, starting 4 factions are especially gimped. Space marines have it the worst, one DLC has 8 of their units. Yeah you also have to buy them for AI to play too even if you're not interested. That's 16 DLC total, and approaches Paradox levels of nickel-and-diming.

Those are not cheap DLCs either, going for like 16.5 euro for a faction and 6-10 euro for a reinforcement pack. That's almost 200 euro worth of DLCs on top of 40 euro for a base game (released in 2018, 7 years ago). DLCs you won't easily be able to ignore, as I've said. Sales? 40% tops. Season passes or bundles? You get complete edition bundle with like 20% discount for 190 euros for the game + all DLCs and that’s it. Truly a Games Workshop product

Not even that, take something like Total War Warhammer for example. True, there's even more DLCs, over three games, but they are better priced, better discounted, better grouped, and most importantly, available for AI to use. You don't have to pay for a shiny new chaos dwarf DLC if you just want to krump them in your game, they get added in a patch with other quality of life upgrades. You can stick to your starting roster if you like and have lot's of variety in your enemies. If you feel so inclined, you can pick up another faction DLC and have a comprehensive playthrough without being hamstrung by the fact you don't own every other DLC first. And DLCs are crossgame, you buy Norsca in TW:W1, you can play them in TW:W13 if you want. Even stupid blood god dlc you only have to buy once and it's very cheap.

See, that's what I expected going into Gladius. TW:W1 also predates Gladius by 2 years, so the precedent was there. Another good option would be to have cheaper bundles or maybe season passes. Currently I just think that Gladius has a petty policy and is way too expensive for what it is. From what I gather, the developer's next game, ZEPHON, is much better in this regard. True, it lacks wh40k IP, but I think I'd rather play ZEPHON than Gladius.

Oh, and soundtrack is kinda meh.

Having legally accumulated a dozen Warhammer titles across various game launchers, I find myself in a peculiar situation. These games have all made their way into my library through the allure of free giveaways, raising questions about the underlying strategy behind this generosity.

Upon closer inspection, the mystery begins to unravel, as it becomes evident that the majority of these games feature expensive DLC. This seemingly altruistic approach, offering the core experience at no cost, appears to be a calculated tactic designed to entice players into investing in additional content down the line.

While it's true that nobody forced my hand in accepting these free-to-claim Warhammer games, the eye-watering £136 price tag for DLC content in this seven year old title leaves me questioning the true value of such offerings.

This substantial cost seems almost comical in the context of an ostensibly free game, raising concerns about the genuine accessibility of these titles for players who cannot or choose not to invest in additional content. As the gaming industry continues to blur the lines between free and paid experiences, it is vital for gamers to weigh the long-term financial implications of entering a world where the full enjoyment of a title hinges on substantial further investment.

As we traverse this increasingly convoluted landscape of free games and costly DLC, it is important to approach such offerings with a discerning eye, recognizing that true value often extends beyond the initial price tag – or lack thereof.

Want an APC for your guards? Chimera is a DLC unit? Land raider? in another DLC with stuff you might not care about for other races. Immortals? DLC again. so that's like almost half the roster locked behind a wall of DLCs, starting 4 factions are especially gimped. Space marines have it the worst, one DLC has 8 of their units. Those are not cheap DLCs either, going for like 16.5 euro for a faction and 6-10 euro for a reinforcement pack. That's almost 200 euro worth of DLCs on top of 40 euro for a base game (released in 2018, 7 years ago). DLCs you won't easily be able to ignore, as I've said. Sales? 40% tops. Season passes or bundles? You get complete edition bundle with like 20% discount for 190 euros for the game + all DLCs and that’s it. Truly a Games Workshop product

Not even that, take something like Total War Warhammer for example. True, there's even more DLCs, over three games, but they are better priced, better discounted, better grouped, and most importantly, available for AI to use. Having legally accumulated a dozen Warhammer titles across various game launchers, I find myself in a peculiar situation. These games have all made their way into my library through the allure of free giveaways, raising questions about the underlying strategy behind this generosity.

Upon closer inspection, the mystery begins to unravel, as it becomes evident that the majority of these games feature expensive DLC. This seemingly altruistic approach, offering the core experience at no cost, appears to be a calculated tactic designed to entice players into investing in additional content down the line.

While it's true that nobody forced my hand in accepting these free-to-claim Warhammer games, the eye-watering £136 price tag for DLC content in this seven year old title leaves me questioning the true value of such offerings.

This substantial cost seems almost comical in the context of an ostensibly free game, raising concerns about the genuine accessibility of these titles for players who cannot or choose not to invest in additional content. As the gaming industry continues to blur the lines between free and paid experiences, it is vital for gamers to weigh the long-term financial implications of entering a world where the full enjoyment of a title hinges on substantial further investment.

As we traverse this increasingly convoluted landscape of free games and costly DLC, it is important to approach such offerings with a discerning eye, recognizing that true value often extends beyond the initial price tag – or lack thereof.
